msDesc.head: A collection of carols; English and Latin; second half of fifteenth century.

msItem.incipit: þe borys hed haue we in broȝht
msItem.bibl: IMEV 3312; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 68; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 293

msItem.incipit:
Of X and M and
oþyr too
Of I and E I syng all soo
X for crystys hym selfe was dyth
msItem.bibl: IMEV 4241; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 69; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 44
msItem.note: Beneath is written Cum cor nostro erat anima

msItem.incipit:
Nowell nowell ell ell I wys yt ys a wundyr nowell
Jhes>u restyd in a may
msItem.explicit:
hosyll and schirft at oure endynge
Nowell ell ell
msItem.bibl: IMEV 1744; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 69-70; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 47

msItem.incipit:
A A A A gaudet cely domina
Mary myld for loue of þe
msItem.bibl: IMEV 2098; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 70; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 145-6

msItem.incipit:
A dere god qwat I am fayn
for I am madyn now gane
þis enþyr day I mete a clerke
msItem.explicit: Wyt h me a clerk for to pley
msItem.bibl: IMEV 3594; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 71; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 277

msItem.incipit:
A A A A salue caterria
lystyn lordygnys qwatte I xall sey
msItem.bibl: IMEV 1900; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 71-2; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 191
msItem.note: Beneath is written: Qwan cryst was borne

msItem.incipit:
I may syng and sey jwys gre mercy my owne
In euery plas qwere
þat I wende
msItem.explicit: þan I may I well my song vowyn
msItem.bibl: IMEV 1484; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 72; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 230-1

msItem.incipit:
Lullay lay lay lay my dere
modyr lullay
As I me lay þis endyres nyth
msItem.bibl: IMEV 352, stanzas 1-9; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 72-3

msItem.incipit: Qwan cryst was borne in bedlem
msItem.bibl: IMEV 3931; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 74-5; Brown, Religious Lyrics of the XVth Century , pp. 127-30

msItem.incipit:
Lollay lay lay lay my dere
modyre lullay
Lullay my chyld
A chyld ys borne ewys
msItem.explicit:
for us he deyd on tre
vt supra
msItem.bibl: IMEV 30; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 76; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 85-6

msItem.incipit:
pray we to ȝoure lady dere for here holy grace
Sche saw þeis women all bedene
msItem.explicit:
þat þei sene he neuer
in face
msItem.bibl: IMEV 3098; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 76-7; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 233
msItem.note: Above first line on f. 7r, in another hand: I what maner mane

msItem.incipit: Now ys þe xij day com
msItem.bibl: IMEV 2339; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 77-9; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 73-4

msItem.incipit:
fadyr my wyll yt is nolo mortem peccatoris
Fadyr I am þin owyn chylde
msItem.explicit:
þis is goddys owyn word ywys
vt supra
msItem.bibl: IMEV 782; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 79-80; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 168

msItem.incipit:
War þat war þat war þat wele wemen be as trew as stele
Stel is gud I sey non odyr
msItem.explicit:
and ȝyt for ny ned to play þe faytur
vt supra
msItem.bibl: IMEV 3214; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 80; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 236

msItem.incipit:
Ay ay be þis day ywyll mak mery qwyll y may
Qwyll mene haue her bornys full
msItem.explicit: for Iak rekles is my name
msItem.bibl: IMEV 4078; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 80-1; Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 246

msItem.incipit: Now Jhesus rector anime ne cademus sustine
msItem.bibl: IMEV 972 (and delete 3654); James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 81-2 (as two items); Greene, The Early English Carols, p. 168, 218 (likewise)
msItem.note: At the head of f. 10v is written (in Scribe A’s hand): Nowell. Taken by editors as the beginning of a new text, it is a false start for item 18 on f. 12r

msItem.incipit:
A newyr a newyr þe chyld was borne
fadyr of hewyn hys owyn son haue sende
hys cyn gdom for to clemyn
þe chyld was borne þis endyr nyth
msItem.bibl: IMEV 3329; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 83; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 91-2

msItem.incipit:
Nowell nowell ell ell I pray ȝow lystyn qwat I ȝow tell
Ouer all gatis that I haff gon
msItem.explicit: And love well Ivy euery schon
msItem.bibl: IMEV 2375; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, pp. 83-4; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 83-4

msItem.incipit:
Women ben good for love "
that sit above
In evyn þer sitte a lady
msItem.bibl: IMEV 1492; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 86; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 294

msItem.incipit:
d wasche ȝe and goo to met in honest
ȝe xall ete
msItem.bibl: IMEV 4256.3; James and Macaulay, Fifteenth Century Carols, p. 85; Greene, The Early English Carols, pp. 293

msItem.note: Fragments of another carol or similar composition; a few isolated words only visible.

foliation.p: Modern foliation added in pencil: a, 1-15

collation.p: One quire of sixteen leaves, constructed by nesting together two divided sets of octofolia (only partly cut).

condition.p: The manuscript is worn and dirty, and the final leaves (ff. 13 and 14) are extremely damaged.
The first and last leaves (ff. a and 15) remain only as tiny stubs, barely photographable.
The pages that remain are fragile, although recent conservation work has done much to stabilize their condition.

layout.p: Texts entered in one column, with refrains frequently added at the right hand side of the page.

handDesc.p: Two scribes (here called ‘A’ and ‘B’) collaborated in the copying, and are clearly distinguishable on the first surviving page (f. 1r), where Scribe A wrote the first four lines, and Scribe B the remainder. Their division of labour is as follows: Item 1, A; item 2, B; item 3, A; items 4-6, B; items 7-8, A; item 9, B; item 10, first two lines (the refrain), A, remainder B; item 11, B; item 12, lines 1-3 and 5, B, remainder A; items 13-15, A; item 16, B (except the word ‘Nowell’, not part of this text, at head of f. 10v, in A’s hand); item 17, B; items 18-19, A; item 20, B. Here and there both scribes have added minor features (e.g. omitted refrains) to one another’s work. Frequent changes in inking and in the cut of the pen shows that they were only able to give intermittent attention to their project.

Scribe A’s hand is the smaller and neater of the two, predominantly
current anglicana in aspect, using the characteristic reverse ‘e’, long ‘r’, the more complex form of ‘w’, and a sigma-shaped final ‘s’; the single-compartment forms of ‘a’ and ‘g’ however are drawn from the repertoire of the
secretary script, though the double-compartmented
anglicana ‘g’ also appears occasionally.

Scribe B’s hand is larger, and the writer’s control of the pen was sometimes poor, giving the work a coarser appearance. The mixture of
anglicana and
secretary forms is similar to A’s. Both scribes employ the obsolete character yogh (ȝ), though not frequently or consistently, and both use the letter ‘y’ to signify both ‘y’ and the runic letter thorn (þ). Where thorn is intended it is so printed in the transcriptions of the incipits and explicits in the list of contents above.

Both scribes were called upon to write occasional lines in Latin, and where these occur it is evident that both were familiar with the conventional forms of abbreviation used at the time, e.g. those signifying ‘er’, ‘ra’, ‘ri’, and ‘us’, and the same forms are sometimes used in rendering English words. The common mark of abbreviation (or tilde) is occasionally written in the form of a dot surmounted by a crescent by Scribe A, but normally both scribes use the simple horizontal bar. Both scribes likewise employ a conventional symbol to signify ‘and’ (or Latin ‘et’), resembling a ‘2’ or a ‘z’, often with an anticipatory looped flourish, and sometimes surmounted with a tilde. Commonly occurring English words are sometimes abbreviated by using superscript letters (e.g. ‘wt’ for ‘with’, ‘þt’ for ‘that’), and it is noticeable that both scribes share the habit of writing superscripts in some words where no abbreviation is intended (e.g. ‘þe’ for ‘þe’, ‘þis’ for ‘þis’). The plural and genitive inflexions of nouns are occasionally represented by a loop and a descending stroke (sometimes mistaken for a long ‘s’); where the forms are given in full, both scribes normally write ‘-ys’.
Virtually no punctuation is used by either scribe, though both place brackets at line-endings (sometimes rather haphazardly) to indicate rhymes.

bindingDesc.p: Bound in a tattered and rather stiff vellum case-type cover with a fore-edge flap extending from the back cover, folding round over the front cover, and then on, partly around the back cover once more.
There is no sign of any clasp or tie.
bindingDesc.decoNote: At the top-right and bottom-right corners of the front cover, there appears a distinctive and unusual stitched quadrilateral pattern: this does not seem to have served any obvious practical function, and may have been decorative (although any decoration is, and would have been, hidden by the wrap-around cover).
bindingDesc.p: The cover as a whole is rather scrappy, and gives the impression of having being unprofessionally made.

note.p: The manuscript is datable, on textual and palaeographical evidence, to the late fifteenth century.
This is corroborated by the watermark observable in the paper, a common fleur-de-lis above a crown, similar to specimens dated to the 1470s and 1480s.

provenance.p: Cowie (1842) marks the manuscript ‘Olim TB’, suggesting that it was one of many in the S sequence at St John’s College acquired from Thomas Baker (d. 1739).

projectDesc.p: This manuscript description and / or transcription was created for Scriptorium: Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts Online.

div.p:
I may syng and sey jwys gre mercy my owne
In euery plas qwere
þat I wende
My purse is my owne frende
Þer for gladly may I syng
gre mercy my own purse
Qwere so euer I goo in lond
My purse is redy at my hond
Þer for þis is a redy song
Vt supra
Qwere so I walke be þe way
My purse xall help me all vay
Þer for may I syng and say
vt supra
If I be out jn þe cuntre
And my purse be far fro me
Þann most I on beggyng fle
And far xall go
and letyll xall haue
And ȝe woll wyth fellechyp won
Taþ ȝoure purse in
ȝore bosom
Þan I may I well my song vowyn

Pray we to ȝoure lady dere for here holy grace
Sche saw þeis women all bedene
Both for sorow and fro tene
Madys and wyuys and weduys I weme
all be þei fayre
in face
Women be both good and hend
Clen curteys cumly
and kend
Yche a cupany is wele amede
Yf a woman be in a plase
Of a woman com all oure blys
Þer for I loue hem all jwys
Qwo so euer seyth on hem amys
be god he ȝawyd in hys face
Were a man i sore
syynge
a woman xall hym out bryng
And wyth a kys lesse hys mornyg
and sette hym
in solace
Þies men arne falce fekyll in thoȝth
Women be wood þat trow hem howt
For welle þie hote and hold itnoth
but spek i here
song
dere lady to þi son þou pray
he synd þeis women oshe wylle may
for false men
þat downe hym tray
þat þei sene he neuer
in face
